title: Can a company that is dissolved file for bankruptcy?
question: My corp. had a judgment against it. Then I closed the company and dissolved it. Now the creditor is,trying to take a debtor exam. Does,the company still,have a right to file for bk?
answers:
Perhaps my colleagues will correct me but I have a totally different view. In a corporate dissolution, the certificate of dissolution must state that all the assets and liabilities have been distributed. Accordingly, the corporate protection is now gone, and the individual shareholders have their proportional distribution of assets, or in this case liabilities.

I would not counsel a client to dissolve an insolvent corportion but instead to file chapter 7 or, as one of my colleagues alludes to, let the creditor run after non-existent assets.

I cannot at all understand how a entity which no longer exists has standing or capacity to file under the bankruptcy code as a matter of state law. Perhaps there is a federal statute that would provide differently.

So my answer would be no.

Yes, a corporation can file for BK but why? A debtor exam will be far less expensive than a corporate BK. If the corporation has no assets, the exam should be very short. Did you or anyone else sign a personal guarantee for the corporation's debt? If so, and if the judgment is substantial, you might want to consider filing individual BK instead. If you still have questions, contact me for a free consultation by clicking the tab across from my name "Contact this lawyer now".

Are you certain the creditor is pursuing a debtor exam for the corporation, or for you personally as a guarantor of corporate debt, perhaps?

A few things to be aware of before proceeding:

As mentioned already, corporation filing for bankruptcy must be represented by an attorney - it cannot file pro se, as an individual/couple may choose.

Also, a corporation will not receive a discharge once the chapter 7 bankruptcy concludes. There may be other reasons for filing bankruptcy, such as having a trustee formally administer any remaining assets, putting all creditors on notice of insolvency (and corporation's dissolution), etc.

Finally, a corporation's bankruptcy filing typically requires board resolution permitting the corporation to file bankruptcy ( true even if a closely- held corporation/opened and operated by a single individual).
Yes, A dissolved corporation can file bankruptcy. You will need an attorney though. A none attorney can not file bankruptcy for a corporation. A corp must be represented by an attorney.
